articles.headline: Talks With G.O.P. on Financial Bill at ‘Impasse,’ Dodd Says
articles.snippet: Senator Christopher J. Dodd said that Democrats would forge ahead with their own bill, after months of talks aimed at reaching a bipartisan consensus.
articles.abstract: Senator Christopher J. Dodd said that Democrats would forge ahead with their own bill, after months of talks aimed at reaching a bipartisan consensus.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two months of Senate negotiations over legislation to rewrite financial regulations  a top priority of the Obama administration  fell apart on Friday amid wrangling over a proposal to create a consumer financial protection agency that would oversee credit cards, mortgages and other products.

articles.headline: BAE Settles Corruption Charges
articles.snippet: The military contractor BAE Systems has reached a settlement of about $450 million with Britain and the U.S., ending a long-running corruption investigation.
articles.abstract: The military contractor BAE Systems has reached a settlement of about $450 million with Britain and the U.S., ending a long-running corruption investigation.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAE Systems, Europe’s largest military contractor, agreed on Friday to plead guilty to two criminal charges and pay nearly $450 million in penalties in the United States and Britain to end long-running investigations into questionable payments made to win huge contracts overseas.
articles.byline: By Christopher Drew and Nicola Clark

articles.headline: Under Siege in Europe
articles.snippet: For the 16 countries that use the euro, a question about whether a single central bank can manage the divergent economic and financial conditions of its members.
articles.abstract: For the 16 countries that use the euro, a question about whether a single central bank can manage the divergent economic and financial conditions of its members.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fortress Europe is now under attack by the market.

articles.headline: Euro Debt Crisis Is Political Test for Bloc
articles.snippet: Anxieties about the euro go to the central dilemma of the European Union: the grip of states over economic policy.
articles.abstract: Anxieties about the euro go to the central dilemma of the European Union: the grip of states over economic policy.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS  What began with worries about the solvency of Greece in the face of high deficits, fake budget figures and low growth has quickly become the most severe test of the 16-nation euro zone in its 11-year history.

articles.headline: Some See Restraint in Goldman Chief’s Bonus
articles.snippet: The sum paid to Lloyd C. Blankfein, $9 million in deferred stock, reflects a sensitive political calculation following the uproar over bankers’ pay.
articles.abstract: The sum paid to Lloyd C. Blankfein, $9 million in deferred stock, reflects a sensitive political calculation following the uproar over bankers’ pay.
articles.lead_paragraph: Once again, a bonus at Goldman Sachs has all of Wall Street talking  only this time, over how small it is.
articles.byline: By Graham Bowley and Eric Dash

articles.headline: The Odds of a Disability Are Themselves Odd
articles.snippet: The disability insurance industry would love for you to buy a policy and has the scary numbers to sway you.
articles.abstract: The disability insurance industry would love for you to buy a policy and has the scary numbers to sway you.
articles.lead_paragraph: You have an 80 percent chance of becoming disabled during your working years.

articles.headline: Bruised Maid Dies at 12, and Pakistan Seethes
articles.snippet: The death of Shazia Masih has served as a vivid reminder of the powerlessness of the poor in Pakistan.
articles.abstract: The death of Shazia Masih has served as a vivid reminder of the powerlessness of the poor in Pakistan.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAHORE, Pakistan  The death already seemed like a bitter injustice. A maid died after unexplained injuries she got in the house of her rich employer. But one detail in particular has outraged Pakistanis: she was 12.

articles.headline: Palin, Visible and Vocal, Is Positioned for Variety of Roles
articles.snippet: Sarah Palin, who headlines a national Tea Party convention on Saturday, represents a new breed of unelected public figures in an environment where politics, news and celebrity are fused as never before.
articles.abstract: Sarah Palin, who headlines a national Tea Party convention on Saturday, represents a new breed of unelected public figures in an environment where politics, news and celebrity are fused as never before.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Without leaving home, Sarah Palin will be able to reach much of her political base, courtesy of a soon-to-be-built television studio in her living room paid for by her newest media patron, Fox News. From her house in Wasilla, Alaska, Ms. Palin also sends missives to 1.3 million Facebook “fans,” writes newspaper columns, Tweets and signs copies of her book for donors.

articles.headline: After Unemployment Ends, Pain and Trauma May Linger
articles.snippet: People returning to work after a period of unemployment are grappling with newfound insecurities and scaled-back budgets; reshaped priorities and broken relationships.
articles.abstract: People returning to work after a period of unemployment are grappling with newfound insecurities and scaled-back budgets; reshaped priorities and broken relationships.
articles.lead_paragraph: RALEIGH, N.C. — Antje Newby went back to work in September, but she has still not escaped the burden imposed by nine months of unemployment.

articles.headline: One Bowl = 2 Servings. F.D.A. May Fix That.
articles.snippet: The F.D.A. may update serving sizes for foods like chips, cookies and ice cream to reflect how Americans really eat.
articles.abstract: The F.D.A. may update serving sizes for foods like chips, cookies and ice cream to reflect how Americans really eat.
articles.lead_paragraph: Seeking a new weapon in the fight against obesity, the Food and Drug Administration wants to encourage manufacturers to post vital nutritional information, including calorie counts, on the front of food packages.

articles.headline: Toyota Has Pattern of Slow Response on Safety Issues
articles.snippet: Toyota’s recent recalls and disclosures are part of a long-term pattern in which the automaker has reacted slowly to safety concerns.
articles.abstract: Toyota’s recent recalls and disclosures are part of a long-term pattern in which the automaker has reacted slowly to safety concerns.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article is by James Kanter, Micheline Maynard and Hiroko Tabuchi.
articles.byline: By James Kanter, Micheline Maynard and Hiroko Tabuchi

articles.headline: This Crisis Won’t Stop Moving
articles.snippet: Investors should prepare for more market gyrations as painful deleveraging continues around the globe.
articles.abstract: Investors should prepare for more market gyrations as painful deleveraging continues around the globe.
articles.lead_paragraph: YOU know we’re in trouble when we’re told that the economic problems in Greece, Portugal and Spain, the most indebted countries in the euro zone, are likely to remain safely contained in those nations.

articles.headline: Testy Conflict With Goldman Helped Push A.I.G. to Edge
articles.snippet: The bank’s demands for billions of dollars from the insurer bled it of cash, which the government later provided.
articles.abstract: The bank’s demands for billions of dollars from the insurer bled it of cash, which the government later provided.
articles.lead_paragraph: Billions of dollars were at stake when 21 executives of Goldman Sachs and the American International Group convened a conference call on Jan. 28, 2008, to try to resolve a rancorous dispute that had been escalating for months.
articles.byline: By Gretchen Morgenson and Louise Story

articles.headline: Is Greece’s Debt Trashing the Euro?
articles.snippet: Greece’s problems, and those looming over its neighbors, have laid bare the dangers of divergent fiscal and political policies in the euro zone.
articles.abstract: Greece’s problems, and those looming over its neighbors, have laid bare the dangers of divergent fiscal and political policies in the euro zone.
articles.lead_paragraph: Athens

articles.headline: Tea Party Looks to Move From Fringe to Force
articles.snippet: Organizers and attendees want to turn the Tea Party into a serious political force and reject the label of an angry fringe group.
articles.abstract: Organizers and attendees want to turn the Tea Party into a serious political force and reject the label of an angry fringe group.
articles.lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — Yes, there were the handful of Revolutionary War re-enactors with their powdered wigs and tri-corner hats. And the man with the T-shirt proclaiming himself a proud member of the “Tennessee MOB” — a poke at politicians who dismissed Tea Party members as an “angry mob.” And one speaker did insist that Jesus’ birth was better documented than President Obama’s.

articles.headline: Battle of the Bands: Citigroup Is Up Next
articles.snippet: A private equity firm, Terra Firma, and its lender, Citigroup, are fighting in court over possession of the music company EMI.
articles.abstract: A private equity firm, Terra Firma, and its lender, Citigroup, are fighting in court over possession of the music company EMI.
articles.lead_paragraph: AFTER the Grammy Awards last Sunday, the stars came out for EMI’s party at the W Hollywood Hotel. The country music hunk Keith Urban arrived with his wife, Nicole Kidman. Katy (“I Kissed a Girl”) Perry sparkled in a form-fitting dress that would become gossip fodder on the Internet. There were also rappers (Cypress Hill), guitar heroes (Slash and Dave Navarro) and a coffeehouse darling (Norah Jones).

articles.headline: Bleak Portrait of Haiti Orphanages Raises Fears
articles.snippet: Authorities fear some orphanages are taking advantage of the chaos to round up children sell them as servants and sex slaves.
articles.abstract: Authorities fear some orphanages are taking advantage of the chaos to round up children sell them as servants and sex slaves.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  The floors were concrete and the windows were broken.

articles.headline: Obama Plans Bipartisan Summit on Health Care
articles.snippet: The meeting would mark the first time in the long health care debate that leaders from both sides would be allowed to air their ideas publicly.
articles.abstract: The meeting would mark the first time in the long health care debate that leaders from both sides would be allowed to air their ideas publicly.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama said Sunday that he would convene a half-day bipartisan health care session at the White House to be televised live this month, a high-profile gambit that will allow Americans to watch as Democrats and Republicans try to break their political impasse.

articles.headline: Plentiful Content, So Cheap
articles.snippet: Demand Media pays $15 to $20 on average for an article -- videos are about $30 -- but the company has no trouble finding steady contributors.
articles.abstract: Demand Media pays $15 to $20 on average for an article -- videos are about $30 -- but the company has no trouble finding steady contributors.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last Wednesday, I met with an executive from Demand Media, a company that generates content based on popular Web searches and other data. Since then, I’ve spent about 20 hours reading past articles, calling people for background, doing interviews, writing my column, and working on the copy with editors Sunday afternoon.

articles.headline: The Fight Over Who Sets Prices at the Online Mall
articles.snippet: Major brands and manufacturers — and now, book publishers — are deploying new tactics and tools to control how their products are presented and priced online.
articles.abstract: Major brands and manufacturers — and now, book publishers — are deploying new tactics and tools to control how their products are presented and priced online.
articles.lead_paragraph: Where’s the price?

articles.headline: On Afghan Road, Scenes of Beauty and Death
articles.snippet: A road that runs through a mountain gorge between Kabul and Jalalabad holds its own terrors.
articles.abstract: A road that runs through a mountain gorge between Kabul and Jalalabad holds its own terrors.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAROBI, Afghanistan  Even in a nation beset by war and suicide bombings, you would be hard-pressed to find anything as reliably terrifying as the national highway through the Kabul Gorge.

articles.headline: After Turmoil at Merrill, Thain Will Lead the Lender CIT
articles.snippet: John A. Thain is seeking to leave behind the controversies that haunted his final days at Merrill after it was acquired by Bank of America.
articles.abstract: John A. Thain is seeking to leave behind the controversies that haunted his final days at Merrill after it was acquired by Bank of America.
articles.lead_paragraph: Over his 30-year career, John A. Thain has risen to top executive positions at Goldman Sachs, the New York Stock Exchange and Merrill Lynch.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: A Well-Written War, Told in the First Person
articles.snippet: A new group of soldier-writers explore the futility of war — but wars that they for the most part support.
articles.abstract: A new group of soldier-writers explore the futility of war — but wars that they for the most part support.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Brian Turner was focused on staying alive, not poetry, when he served as an infantry team leader in Iraq. But he quickly saw that his experience  “a year of complete boredom punctuated by these very intense moments”  lent itself to the tautness of verse.

articles.headline: Toyota Is Expected to Add 2010 Prius to Recalls
articles.snippet: The decision to recall at least 311,000 2010 Prius cars will be announced early this week, adding to the automaker’s woes after recalls of other models.
articles.abstract: The decision to recall at least 311,000 2010 Prius cars will be announced early this week, adding to the automaker’s woes after recalls of other models.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO  Toyota plans to recall at least 311,000 of its 2010 Prius hybrid models after receiving a flurry of complaints about the vehicle’s brakes, a person briefed on the decision said late Sunday.

articles.headline: In a Message to Democrats, Wall St. Sends Cash to G.O.P.
articles.snippet: Bankers, unhappy at the president’s proposals for tighter financial regulations, are shifting donations to Republicans.
articles.abstract: Bankers, unhappy at the president’s proposals for tighter financial regulations, are shifting donations to Republicans.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  If the Democratic Party has a stronghold on Wall Street, it is JPMorgan Chase.

articles.headline: European Central Bank in a Squeeze
articles.snippet: As alarm about Greek debt increases, a weakness of the European monetary union has been exposed: its lack of a strong political arm.
articles.abstract: As alarm about Greek debt increases, a weakness of the European monetary union has been exposed: its lack of a strong political arm.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT  Whether he likes it or not, Jean-Claude Trichet is not just the president of the European Central Bank. Mr. Trichet, 67, is also the de facto president of Europe, at least for the 16 nations that rely on the euro as their common currency.

articles.headline: Asia Sails Smoothly Through Debt Waters
articles.snippet: The Asian financial crisis of 1997 led many countries to be more conservative about borrowing and spending than Western nations.
articles.abstract: The Asian financial crisis of 1997 led many countries to be more conservative about borrowing and spending than Western nations.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India  While rising government debt is a growing concern in Europe and the United States, Asia’s economies remain remarkably resilient, even buoyant, underscoring how economic might is shifting from West to East.
articles.byline: By Vikas Bajaj and Keith Bradsher

articles.headline: For Kremlin, Ukraine Election Cuts Two Ways
articles.snippet: Russia’s preferred candidate is the apparent winner, but the starkly contested presidential race contrasts sharply with Russia’s recent history.
articles.abstract: Russia’s preferred candidate is the apparent winner, but the starkly contested presidential race contrasts sharply with Russia’s recent history.
articles.lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine  The apparent victory of Russia’s preferred candidate in the Ukrainian presidential race may be a relief to Vladimir V. Putin, who has long sought to discredit his neighbor’s raucous democracy and its drift to the West.
